channel.title: [Hyperion]FroyoScape's Runecrafting[Base] - Includes my new skilling system!

item.title: [Hyperion]FroyoScape's Runecrafting[Base] - Includes my new skilling system!
item.dc:creator: @arham_4 arham 4
item.description:
@arham_4 wrote:

[quote=“Clawz fury, post:14, topic:494131”]Why are you using an interface for this… lol? And why do you have two interfaces? The design makes no sense. Make an abstract class.

The only abstract methods you need are pretty much one to reset the skill, and one for the exp rate for the skill… You can also make an execute method although that design is flawed and is evident in your system. How? It doesn’t support all skills:

For example

public void execute(Player player, int objectId);

Not all skills use an object (herblore, fletching, fishing, crafting, thieving, slayer, etc.) , and some skills may require more parameters than just an integer.

Change the execute method to a reset method, to reset the skill. You don’t need an execute method, you can simply make a static method with an instance of the player as a parameter or you can instance the class in the Player class; and call some sort of “start” method from there. You’ll notice once you start working on skills like fishing and cooking, that your ‘base’ is pretty much useless, or extremely hard to work with.

Seems like you haven’t really grasped the concept of inheritance yet, but good job arham! Keep working hard :)[/quote]
Thanks! I’ll be sure to keep this in mind.

Read full topic
item.source: [Hyperion]FroyoScape's Runecrafting[Base] - Includes my new skilling system!

item.title: [Hyperion]FroyoScape's Runecrafting[Base] - Includes my new skilling system!
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

Why are you using an interface for this… lol? And why do you have two interfaces? The design makes no sense. Make an abstract class.

The only abstract methods you need are pretty much one to reset the skill, and one for the exp rate for the skill… You can also make an execute method although that design is flawed and is evident in your system. How? It doesn’t support all skills:

For example

public void execute(Player player, int objectId);

Not all skills use an object (herblore, fletching, fishing, crafting, thieving, slayer, etc.) , and some skills may require more parameters than just an integer.

Change the execute method to a reset method, to reset the skill. You don’t need an execute method, you can simply make a static method with an instance of the player as a parameter or you can instance the class in the Player class; and call some sort of “start” method from there. You’ll notice once you start working on skills like fishing and cooking, that your ‘base’ is pretty much useless, or extremely hard to work with.

Seems like you haven’t really grasped the concept of inheritance yet, but good job arham! Keep working hard

item.title: [Hyperion]FroyoScape's Runecrafting[Base] - Includes my new skilling system!
item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

[quote=“arham 4, post:12, topic:494131”][quote author=LilXCj link=topic=612364.msg4254458#msg4254458 date=1362509178]
Otherwise, this looks nice. Except for the fact that this doesn’t teach me anything. Just tells me where to put stuff in a blank hyperion.
[/quote]
The code is documented.[/quote]

Not trying to sound like an ass but just because code is documented doesn’t merit calling this a tutorial or saying it will teach me anything.

Just cause I see:

/** * All the altars of the Runecrafting skill. * * @see org.hyperion.rs2.model.skills.impl.RunecraftingSkill */
and various of documentation just tells me its there for that reason. For this tutorial to be successful in teaching people how to make a runecrafting base you should tell us why you picked the method of programming and the approach you took with your code.

Why did you use an array in such and such area and like reflex says, why use a boolean? What made you take that approach and why should other people take that approach in creating systems like this, in this case runecrafting.

Not sure if that’s going to get my point across.

Read full topic
item.source: [Hyperion]FroyoScape's Runecrafting[Base] - Includes my new skilling system!

item.title: [Hyperion]FroyoScape's Runecrafting[Base] - Includes my new skilling system!
item.dc:creator: @arham_4 arham 4
item.description:
@arham_4 wrote:

LilXCj:

Otherwise, this looks nice. Except for the fact that this doesn’t teach me anything. Just tells me where to put stuff in a blank hyperion.

The code is documented.

[quote=“relexlawl, post:11, topic:494131”]Critism incoming:

Skill interface:

- Why is there a boolean for isSkilling? If the skill instance is called they're obviously skilling.

- The point of a skill system is to make writing skills easier and neater, also not rewriting code, i.e from harvesting skills, where it's basically, animation - harvest - repeat.

- The interface basically does nothing, but make having execute and isSkilling necessary methods.

- For this kind of thing abstraction would be best.

SkillConstants:

- why is isSkilling boolean array static? Static means there's only ONE global state for the array, meaning if one of the values in the array is turned to true for 1 player, it will be true for every player in the server.

- Seems rather pointless really.[/quote]

Ty will work on this next time.

Read full topic

Skill interface:

- Why is there a boolean for isSkilling? If the skill instance is called they're obviously skilling.

- The point of a skill system is to make writing skills easier and neater, also not rewriting code, i.e from harvesting skills, where it's basically, animation - harvest - repeat.

- The interface basically does nothing, but make having execute and isSkilling necessary methods.

- For this kind of thing abstraction would be best.

SkillConstants:

- why is isSkilling boolean array static? Static means there's only ONE global state for the array, meaning if one of the values in the array is turned to true for 1 player, it will be true for every player in the server.

- Seems rather pointless really.

item.title: [Hyperion]FroyoScape's Runecrafting[Base] - Includes my new skilling system!
item.dc:creator: @arham_4 arham 4
item.description:
@arham_4 wrote:

[center][/center]

[center][shadow=cyan,left][size=24pt][tt]FroyoScape’s[/tt] Runecrafting BASE[/size][/shadow]

Contains:

  • All singular runes
  • All multiples

Bugs:

  • Messages show even if you have the requirements.

Read before criticism:

  • It’s HIGHLY suggested you convert this to an action.
  • Fix the bugs yourself.
  • Do remember, this was made for 319 cache, so that means there are NO pure essence.[/center]

[size=18pt]Step 1:[/size]
Setting the base up.

Make a new package. I suggest it to be org.hyperion.rs2.model.skills or org.hyperion.rs2.content.skills. Inside that package, make another package. Name it either org.hyperion.rs2.model.skills.impl or org.hyperion.rs2.content.skills.impl. We’ve got the packages set up.

NOTE: This uses package org.hyperion.rs2.model.skills and package org.hyperion.rs2.model.skills.impl. If you use the other one, you’ll need to convert the packaging in the class.

[size=18pt]Step 2:[/size]
Implementing my skilling system.

In org.hyperion.rs2.model.skills or org.hyperion.rs2.content.skills, make a new java class and name it Skill.java. In it, add the following:

package org.hyperion.rs2.model.skills;

import org.hyperion.rs2.model.Player;

/**
 * @author Arham 4
 * 
 *         An interface that manages the skills in an organized manner.
 */
public interface Skill {

	/**
	 * Is the player skilling?
	 * 
	 * @return SkillConstants.isSkilling[SkillConstants.SKILLNAME];
	 */
	public boolean isSkilling();

	/**
	 * Executes the skill.
	 */
	public void execute(Player player, int objectId);

}

This is an interface. Why do we have this? So the classes look more tidy. Think of this as a pre-formatted layout of a class that implements this.

Now, after doing so, make another java class file. Name it SkillConstants. Inside it, you add:

package org.hyperion.rs2.model.skills;

/**
 * @author Arham 4
 * 
 *         The variables for skills.
 */
public final class SkillConstants {

	/**
	 * Is the player skilling?
	 */
	public final static boolean[] isSkilling = new boolean[25];

	/**
	 * Resets the <code>isSkilling</code> boolean.
	 */
	public static void resetActiveness() {
		for (int skill = 0; skill < isSkilling.length; skill++)
			isSkilling[skill] = false;
	}

}

This is just setting the skills active or not, so it’s easier to manage.

Now, make a new java class file (Last one in this step, I swear!) and name it SkillData. Inside it, add:

package org.hyperion.rs2.model.skills;

/**
 * @author Arham 4
 * 
 *         Manages all the data classes.
 */
public interface SkillData {

}

I only made this because the org.hyperion.rs2.model.skills.impl (or org.hyperion.rs2.content.skills.impl) is impl, AKA implement, and skill an interface is implement, I just followed the rule of the package by implementing this interface to all the data classes (Yes, I don’t like making all the data and stuff to do in the skill in the same class).

[size=18pt]Step 3:[/size]
Adding my Runecrafting.

Now, in org.hyperion.rs2.model.skills.impl or org.hyperion.rs2.content.skills.impl, make a new java class file called RunecraftingData. Inside it, add:

package org.hyperion.rs2.model.skills.impl;

import org.hyperion.rs2.model.skills.SkillData;

/**
 * @author Arham 4
 * 
 *         The runecrafting skill's data.
 */
public class RunecraftingData implements SkillData {

	/**
	 * All the altars of the Runecrafting skill.
	 * 
	 * @see org.hyperion.rs2.model.skills.impl.RunecraftingSkill
	 */
	public static int[] ALTARS = { 2478, 2479, 2480, 2481, 2482, 2483, 2484,
			2487, 2486, 2485, 2488, 3624 };
	
	/**
	 * All the viable essence of the Runecrafting skill.
	 * 
	 * @see org.hyperion.rs2.model.skills.impl.RunecraftingSkill
	 */
	public static int[] VIABLE_ESSENCE = { 1436, 7636 };

	/**
	 * @author Arham 4
	 * 
	 *         All the data for the Runecrafting skill.
	 * 
	 * @see org.hyperion.rs2.model.skills.impl.RunecraftingSkill
	 */
	public static enum DATA {
		AIR(2478, 556, 5, new int[] { 1, 11, 22, 33, 44, 55, 66, 77, 88, 99 }),
		MIND(2479, 558, 5.5, new int[] { 1, 14, 28, 42, 56, 70, 84, 98 }),
		WATER(2480, 555, 6, new int[] { 5, 19, 38, 57, 76, 95 }),
		EARTH(2481, 557, 6.5, new int[] { 9, 26, 52, 78 }),
		FIRE(2482, 554, 7, new int[] { 14, 35, 70 }),
		BODY(2483, 559, 7.5, new int[] { 20, 46, 92 }),
		COSMIC(2484, 564, 8, new int[] { 27, 59 }),
		CHAOS(2487, 562, 8.5, new int[] { 35, 74 }),
		NATURE(2486, 561, 9, new int[] { 44, 91 }),
		LAW(2485, 563, 9.5, new int[] { 54 }),
		DEATH(2488, 565, 10, new int[] { 65 }),
		BLOOD(30624, 560, 10.5, new int[] { 77 });

		private int alter, rune, multiplier[];
		private double XP;

		/*
		 * The Data enum's constructor.
		 */
		DATA(int alter, int rune, double XP, int[] multiplier) {
			this.alter = alter;
			this.rune = rune;
			this.XP = XP;
			this.multiplier = multiplier;
		}
		
		/*
		 * Gets the alter interacted with.
		 */
		public int getAlter() {
			return alter;
		}
		
		/*
		 * Gets the rune to be generated.
		 */
		public int getRune() {
			return rune;
		}
		
		/*
		 * Gets the EXP recieved.
		 */
		public double getXP() {
			return XP;
		}
		
		/*
		 * The multiplier.
		 */
		public int[] getMultiplier() {
			return multiplier;
		}
	}
}

This handles all the data of this Runecrafting skill.

Now, make a new java file and name it RunecraftingSkill. In it, add the following code:

http://pastebin.com/KJgCsBtP

Everything to do with runecrafting is to be put here.

[size=18pt]Step 4:[/size]
Making this work in-game.

Go to org.hyperion.rs2.model and find the java class file Player. Inside it, find:

	private final ActionSender actionSender = new ActionSender(this);

Below that, add:


	/**
	 * The Runecrafting skill.
	 */
	private final RunecraftingSkill runecraftingSkill = new RunecraftingSkill();

Now, find:

	public ActionSender getActionSender() {

Below the

} of that, add:


	/**
	 * Gets the runecrafting skill class.
	 * 
	 * @return The runecrafting skill class.
	 */
	public RunecraftingSkill getRunecraftingSkill() {
		return runecraftingSkill;
	}

Now, go to org.hyperion.rs2.packet, and inside the class ObjectOptionPacket, find:

private void handleOption1(final Player player, final Packet packet) {

In there, below:

final GameObjectDefinition obj = GameObjectDefinition.forId(id);

Add:

		player.face(loc);
		for (DATA data : DATA.values()) {
			if (id == data.getAlter())
				player.getRunecraftingSkill().execute(player, id);
		}

And presto, we are finished!
If you’ve got any questions, feel free to ask.

Read full topic
